page.title: 13CHESTNUT COPPICE PLANTATIONS
page.content: The Romans were the first to introduce chestnut trees to Britain from Italy nearly 2000 years ago. Now the growing of chestnut trees is a substantial part of the forestry programme of the{Cowdray Estate,}where they are grown on the{lower greensand {soil}from{Buddington Farm}across to {Lodsworth. The chestnut trees are planted four to five feet apart as coppice plants in plantations, on a south facing slope because they need full sunshine for growth. They need a hot, dry summer and a warm, wet winter. When the trees are well-established the trunks are cut down to ground level, to a stump or stool. Clusters of shoots then grow out from the stool. The shoots are cut when of sufficient height. In the warm Summer of 1976, they grew 12 feet high.
